module.name: chemical_substance
module.keywords: module, substance, chemical element, chemical compound, physical particles, CAS registry number

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of substances such as physical particles, chemical elements, compounds and their identification via the CAS registry numbers or similar services, compositions of substances with a specified ratio and the relation of substances to raw material parts.

inscope.li: definition of a substance and its specialisations as physical particle, chemical element, and chemical compound;
definition of the composition of a substance from other substances and their ratios;
a consist-of relationship between a substance and a raw material part.

outscope.li: the definition and representation of a chemical formula;
the inner structure of a substance.

definition.def: a chemical compound is a substance formed from two or more chemical elements, with a fixed ratio determining the composition Dihydrogen monoxide (water, H2O) is a compound composed of two hydrogen atoms for every oxygen atom. In general, this fixed ratio must be fixed due to some sort of physical property, rather than an arbitrary man-made selection. This is why materials such as brass, the superconductor YBCO, the semiconductor aluminium gallium arsenide, or chocolate are considered mixtures or alloys rather than compounds.

a chemical element is a kind of substance that cannot be divided or changed into different substances by ordinary chemical methods The smallest particle of a chemical element is an atom, which consists of electrons centered around a nucleus of protons and neutrons.

a physical particle is a kind of substance from physics covering radiation and all kinds of subatomic and elementary particles Electron, proton, photon and alpha particle are examples of elementary particle.

a substance is the idealised representation of pure matter that possesses definite properties or characteristics Industrial realised products such as raw material are not pure and may have by their specific geometric structure and manufacturing process properties and characteristics which differ from the substance they are made of.
